Milano Mayor Sala: “Inter Want To Invest In The San Siro, Milan Want To Build A New Stadium”

Milano Mayor Giuseppe ‘Beppe’ Sala spoke on the sidelines of a ceremony today on Inter’s plans to build a new training base and headquarters at Piazza D’Armi: “The municipality of Milan has agreed to re-evaluate that area and San Siro, obviously the topic must be dedicated to something that makes sense compared to current needs.”

Sala continued that “Sport is a need and has a value and Milano needs sport. With Inter I see a willingness to invest. Whereas with AC Milan we started discussing the potential of other areas to build a new stadium if necessary: this should be done in a short time, after which it will be decided by the two teams.”

Sala concluded discussing the possibility of Inter having San Siro to themselves “We say that it is not easy in the sense that there is an open contract. However, I repeat that we are working with Milan to figure out how to build a new stadium, otherwise they will remain at San Siro.”

Luciano Spalletti was in for his press conference and he began by discussing the post on his Instagram profile on Anne Frank. “The desire was to do it in a way different to what usually happens when people stop talking about things after a week. A club which chooses to communicate through hate cannot survive. It gives you time to see everyone else's position. Perhaps something else will be written in a few days.”

The San Siro will be almost completely full for tomorrow’s match. “It makes us happy that our fans are there and feel close to us. It makes us feel comfortable and it motivates the team. It’s another sign of their faith in us. When we’ve been in difficulty, I’ve always seen the team react as a united group. If there isn’t good positioning or quick reactions, it will be a tough match. This is a game which could put us in serious difficulty, we’ll make use of the support and the people who wanted to be at San Siro with us.”

Mauro Icardi will miss the call-up to the Argentina squad through injury, as the Inter forward is suffering from tendonitis in his knee. The injury is not expected to be serious, and on Monday or Tuesday Icardi will undergo testing. Depending on the outcome, Icardi could be available for Inter's next match against Atalanta. However, he will miss out on the upcoming match with the national team.

Paris Saint Germain’s Javier Pastore has spoken on his future amid rumours that Inter, among others are courting him with a view to a January transfer.

“When will I leave Paris?” the Argentine, formerly of Palermo pondered before going on to say, “The day I no longer have the feeling of being important to the team, I will leave because for me, playing football is life,” he told Canal+.

The 28-year-old is under contract in the French capital through to 2019 and has also attracted interest from Inter’s city rivals Milan and Premier League club Chelsea.

“At the moment I feel important, I’ve suffered a lot of injuries for a year and a half and this is why I have not played much, it is nothing to do with coaches and I know I’m an important player for PSG.

“Will I stay until the end of the season? I do not know, I think so,” he concluded.

Mauro Icardi this morning underwent a clinical and instrumental assessment at the Humanitas Research Hospital in Rozzano. 

After taking a knock during Sunday’s game against Torino, tests results has since shown that the Nerazzurri attacker has suffered no significant injury, although there is bruising and inflammation around his right knee. 

Before retuning to Luciano Spalletti’s squad, Icardi will now complete four to five days of physiotherapy and an individual training programme.

Quaresma, who is currently playing with Turkish giants Besiktas stated that “some coaches were angry and sometimes they were asking me to cross normally, but I always did it my way. Others thought I did not have to do it and asked me, but then they realized that it was normal for me. It was not a question of lack of respect or lack of concentration.”

In conclusion he addressed the issue of his bad boy image stating that “I’ve never had any problems with any coaches. I’ve always had the reputation of a bad guy, the player who has caused problems everywhere but I’ve never been a big problem. I’m a direct person, I say what I have to say and when you say what you think about football, you’re the bad guy.”

Santos have confirmed that they will hold talks with Inter next week, where Gabriel Barbosa will ‘definitely’ come under discussion.

Gabigol joined Inter for €29.5m from Santos last year but failed to make any starts in his first season with the Nerazzurri, and the young forward has similarly struggled on loan at Benfica.

“We know about Ausilio coming here, and we’re planning to meet him next week,” Luiz Taveira, a spokesman for the Brazilian club, told Calciomercato.com.

“He will watch a match here, before meeting our board. There are so many issues at stake.

“Gabigol possibly returning? Gabigol’s a great player. I like him very much and he likes Santos too, so we’ll definitely talk about him.

“If the Nerazzurri release him, we’ll try to bring him back without thinking twice. There’s always room for Gabigol here.

“Lucas Lima to Inter? Lucas Lima will become a free agent at the end of December. He doesn’t want to sign a new deal, so I can’t say anything else about him.

“We’ve already found his heir, Rodrygo, who was born in 2001 and debuted in our last game against Atletico Mineiro.

“Yuri Alberto? He’s the new Robinho, he’s liked by half of Europe and Real Madrid had even offered €45m for him, but Santos said ‘no’.

“There’s Rodrygo but also Arthur Gomes, a winger that’s already playing for us.”

Lionel Messi and Argentina only have a couple of friendly matches to play. The Argentine star spoke to Tyc Sport about an array of national team topics, including Mauro Icardi, "The truth is coming out, they were all false, especially that we didn't want Icardi in the national squad. I've never put myself in the middle, it's not my way of doing things. I laugh at all of the rumors that I hear, that there are no players of caliber here except for Di Maria, Mascherano and Biglia. To say that they play because they are my friends is a lack of respect toward me and against them. They are all lies. Higuain? The error in 2014 hurts us all. Russia 2018? If we were to leave there as champions, I would vote to walk all the way to the Sanctuary of Saint Nicholas. Regrets? We have played in three finals (a World Cup and two Copa America) and we deserved to win at least two. But things can happen. We suffered a lot to get to this World Cup, but we couldn't be left out and I always believed we would qualify. Now we concentrate on the tournament in Russia, because time flies in a hurry."

Inter's number 10 Joao Mario talked about his situation at Inter in Portugal's press conference: "It's obvious that I'd like to play more. There's some rumors about PSG but I won't let it distract me. Let's see what happens in January. Then I'll decide what is best for me and my career. But I don't want distractions right now".

And Julio Cesar says the current Old Trafford boss's "heroic" achievements at San Siro mean his place in hearts of Nerazzurri fans is secure.
"Mourinho was more than a father to me when I was at Inter," the 38-year-old told ESPN.

"In only two years, Mourinho and his staff helped win everything. Inter contracted Mourinho to win the Champions League. Inter had success in that period winning Serie A, but the Champions League was different. The club had not won it for 42 years. Within two years, Mourinho had won it. It was a heroic win.

"That Inter team and Mourinho will be in the hearts of Inter supporters forever."

Although the veteran keeper is still playing at Benfica, his career with Brazil's national team came to an end in 2014 after they suffered a 7-1 defeat to Germany on home soil in the World Cup semi-finals.

Cesar is sure he will never be able to live the defeat down, and believes it all came down to a crucial 15-minute period.

"Unfortunately, I'll have to reply to this question for the whole of my life," he added. "It's a situation that, until now, the people who played could not find an answer to what happened.

"We met a very strong team who had been prepared since 2006 to win this World Cup in 2014. Germany had been building this team for a long time, their coach explained that. I respected this Germany team a lot. They were very well organised and every player contributed to making them a great team.

Spalletti

The captain Icardi was very influential with a brace as he was decisive once more. “Mauro is a really strong footballer, he’s a bird of prey in the box who pounces on balls in the area. Wins however are determined by the group, we gave up very little and we did well to allow Mauro to score. We played as a team, we did well above all when we had the centre-midfielders getting together with Gagliardini dropping deep, while Miranda and Skriniar then created the right distance between the lines. It wasn’t easy because Atalanta have important players and they’re not easy to take on.”

110 stories to tell each other who we are, day by day.

Santon explained the rationale his squad number, number 17 and where his nickname, “the baby” came from.

“It has given me both some sorrow and some satisfaction, it is important for both good and bad, and in fact I have it tattooed on my arm.

“I was so young that Jose Mourinho treated me like a son. At a press conference, he called me ‘the baby’ and from there everything went off and everyone called me that.”

The 26-year-old spent four years with Newcastle in the Premier League between 2011-2015 and discussed the differences between Premier League and Serie A football.

“There is so much difference. The Premier League is a more physical based and less tactical league. There is a fantastic atmosphere with people at the stadium. I will remember my time in the Premier League forever. It was great to play there.”
Speaking on San Siro Santon declared that the stadium is “unique and is even more beautiful at night.”

Santon then discussed the team as a whole.
“We are good together, even off of the field, we are close.”

The left back concluded by recalling coming up against Cristiano Ronaldo in the Champions League.

“He has always been one of my idols. 6 months ago I only saw him on the Playstation, then I found him in front of myself.”

As reported by Fcinternews the Mayor of Milan, Beppe Sala, discussed Suning’s idea to move the Nerazzurri headquarters to the Piazza d’Armi area. These are the words of the Mayor when he was quizzed on the prospective move: “What do you think about Inter’s project for new headquarters? The discussion has not yet been initiated or tested, and for the moment it is only an idea. I am happy that an area that is somewhat abandoned would become a serious and greener destination which can attract more people towards it. However on the opposite side is that the location will become more private rather than public. Personally I have been positive about the idea, if it makes sense and if the rules are respected, because with everything that will be done around the area on the railway, public and green spaces surrounding the area already, therefore I see this initiative very positively, of course.”

Handanovic: 'No time to breathe'

Samir Handanovic wants Inter to ensure Cagliari “don’t have time to breathe” in tonight’s trip to the Sardegna Arena.

“We know that Cagliari have quality and they’ve had positive results since Diego Lopez took over. You can see the team has more confidence in the way they play,” the goalkeeper told Inter Channel.

“But we are Inter, we know what to do, we’re well prepared and have to prove it on the pitch. We know how to take on Cagliari and trust ourselves.

“We need an Inter-style performance to win the game. We mustn’t give the opposition time to breathe.”

his morning, Matias Vecino underwent an MRI scan to his left thigh after being substituted on Saturday evening against Cagliari. An issue was detected with his biceps femoris muscle. Vecino will follow a personalised plan and his condition will be evaluated day by day.

Mancini takes Inter credit

Roberto Mancini believes he is owed some of the credit for Inter’s unbeaten start to the season. “Many of their players arrived when I was there...”

The likes of Miranda, Marcelo Brozovic and Ivan Perisic joined Inter when Mancini was still Coach back in the summer of 2015, with the trio helping the Nerazzurri to second in Serie A after 10 wins and no defeats in their opening 13 matches.

“I’m happy for Inter. I knew it’d be just a matter of time,” the Zenit St Petersburg boss told Domenica Sportiva.

“Many of their players arrived when I was there. We’d built an important squad: I’m thinking Brozovic, Miranda, Perisic and even Kondogbia, one of the best players in La Liga this season.

“Regrets? No. Sometimes you need dignity, and if things don’t go well, you need the courage to make a change.

“Scudetto? It’ll be contested by those currently near the top if they stay up there. Juve? They never died.”

Dalbert: ‘I got death threats’

Inter full-back Dalbert reveals he got death threats from Nice fans after he pushed for his move to Italy.
The Brazilian was involved in one of the summer’s longest transfer sagas, but he eventually moved to the Nerazzurri on August 9.

“It was all very fast, now I’m living the dream I had as a child,” Dalbert explained to France Football.

“Now I’m playing in a very important club, but I’m not going to stop. I want to leave a mark on Inter’s history and play for the Brazilian national team.

“When I first came to Inter I thought of my family, I wanted to secure their future. Then I thought of myself and the extraordinary experience it would be for me.

“Also my visibility for the national team, when I first came to Nice I told the directors that I wanted to play with the Seleçao, and I knew I’d have more chance of being called while playing for Inter.

“It’s a shame some didn’t understand my decision.”

The perception was that Dalbert forced his way out, and the defender says he even received death threats.

“I didn't have a choice, it was the only way I could win. Nice didn’t respect my will and they didn’t show that they were counting on me.

“The President [Jean-Pierre] Rivère is a comprehensive person, he understood my position but he wanted to defend the interests of the club. That’s totally normal.

“What disappointed me was the lack of consideration. If the directors didn’t want to sell me, they must have wanted me to stay, so at that point they should have valued me more or at the very least discussed improving my contract.

“It’s not about money, but with where I came from I have to insure my family’s future. It’s a necessity, a question of survival, but they said: ‘Dalbert is back from his holidays, he’ll train and everything will be fine’.

“They didn’t offer me anything and they didn’t want to negotiate, which pushed me to leave Nice.

“The players were on my side, in my place they’d have acted the same way. Some didn’t agree, but I had no choice it was the only way I could do it.

“Sometimes I felt guilty but it had to be done, now my conscience is clean/

“The fans? I was a traitor in their eyes, and when they whistled me against Ajax it hurt. I’d like to go back to Nice one day, but I don’t think it will be possible.

“I gave my all for that shirt, and I don’t want to see the anger in the eyes of the fans.

“Before I left I had a lot of threatening messages from them, they said they wanted to break my legs and others hoped to see me dead.

“They also sent messages to my wife through social media to threaten her. I felt their wrath and it hurt me, I hope it will pass. I have a lot of respect for the club and the real fans.”

Wanda: ‘Icardi thinking of Inter’

Mauro Icardi’s wife and agent says “there are top clubs who have been following him” but “he’s thinking of Inter and is happy to be here”.

The striker has been linked with Real Madrid, and his record of 15 goals in 14 Serie A games has raised concern that the €110m release clause in his contract is too low.

“Mauro is an important player, and there are top clubs who have been following him for some time,” Wanda Icardi told Corriere dello Sport.

“It’s right that a striker like that, one of the best number 9s in the world, has big clubs who are interested in him and are considering what he’s worth. But they have to please him and Inter.

“I’d prefer not to tell you who is calling me, I talk about these things while Mauro is thinking of Inter and is happy to be here.

“The directors know he has rejected clubs that other players wouldn’t reject, because he has the Nerazzurri colours in his heart.

“I won’t deny though that a lot of teams are interested in him, many more than you hear around the place…

“Will he move elsewhere in future? It’s difficult to say, because in football you never know what will happen.

“He has a contract, he’s thinking of winning with Inter, he’s happy with what he’s doing and he’s aiming for the maximum.

“No-one knows the future though, the last word is the club’s and there are offers which cannot be refused.

“How much is he worth? At least €200m.”

It has been suggested that the Beneamata will offer a new contract, raising Icardi’s release clause or perhaps removing it altogether.

“It’s a discussion we have to have with the club. It’s up to the directors to say if the current contract is suitable and what they want to do.

“He’s an Inter player, the captain, and he’s always shown that he’s tied to this team. We’re not asking for anything, if the club wants to change something in his contract it’s up to them.

“I asked for the release clause because I thought it was right to give a player of his quality and his level the release clause of a top player.

“I don’t know if the club will want to adjust the clause and, consequently, his contract.

“The clause shouldn’t scare anyone though, even if a club meets the release clause the decision is always up to the player.”

Wanda was also asked about the Inter captain’s start to the season, and she insisted that she isn’t surprised.

“I believe in him and I know what he can do. With this group and this Coach [Luciano Spalletti] it’s going well. Under those conditions he always surprises and gives you even more than usual.

“I like being his agent, because everything stays at home. Mauro makes it easy for me, sometimes when we talk about a renewal he’ll score four or five goals in two games and negotiations get much easier.”

All Inter fans could do for most of the summer months was watch on as their city rivals AC Milan splashed more than €200 million on new players under new Chinese president Yonghong Li and his group of investors.

The Nerazzurri’s response was to spend €7 million on veteran Spanish midfielder Borja Valero, who arrived on an initial three-year deal from Fiorentina. Suffice to say, the Tuscan side’s loss has most definitely been Luciano Spalletti’s gain.

Mauro Icardi

Non ho parole per descrivere questo momento.. un momento bellissimo che rappresenta l’impegno e sacrifici che ho fatto in questi anni all’Inter. Oggi, nella 5 stagione a Milano sono entrato nella Storia di questo Club come 10 marcatore di tutti i tempi. Grazie a tutti voi per il sostegno che mi date ogni giorno.

I have no words to describe this moment .. a beautiful moment that represents the commitment and sacrifices I have made in these years at Inter. Today, in the 5 season in Milan I entered the history of this club as 10th scorer of all time. Thank you all for the support you give me every day.

P44

The Emperor who conquered Milan
Storia N.16/110


It is the 14th August 2001 at the Santiago Bernabéu. Being played out on the pitch is one of the most prestigious friendlies of a long-winded summer pre-season. The encounter between Real Madrid and Inter is stuck at 1-1, while with five minutes remaining a 19-year-old Brazilian makes his entrance. A substitution that shook the match in sudden and significant fashion.

Awarded a free kick on the edge of the area, the order came from Cuper that the young lad should take it. A gift for the debutant in a prestigious friendly? Maybe yes, maybe no. The smiling starlet had already shown his skills in training, although his teammates still did not see this coming. Hit at around 180 kilometres per hour, the ball flew straight in under the crossbar. This was how Adriano Leite Ribeiro introduced himself to his news fans, helping those forget, even just for an instant, another Brazilian who had already donned the Nerazzurri shirt previously.

I have some similar characteristics to Ronaldo, but I am young. I am only 19. I still had a lot to learn and a lot to work on.

When you grow up in Rocinha, one of the most dangerous and infamous Favela neighbourhoods in Brazil, talent can save your life. And as seen in in Milan, where he became an Emperor for everyone, he demonstrated that he had talent in abundance. He had power, pace and an imposing physique, whilst he was also incredibly passionate. A characteristic that was perhaps a double-edged sword as he progressed. His emotion brought him closer to the fans and his teammates, although it often disrupted his play and development when out on the pitch.

However, a perfect demonstration of his raw talent came against Luciano Spalletti’s Udinese side back during the 2004-05 campaign, when he scored an absolutely scintillating brace. These goals were typical of Adriano’s unique style, one that first came to the fore when he was just 19-years-old and conquered Madrid.


ADRIANO LEITE RIBEIRO

Adriano Leite Ribeiro (Rio de Janeiro, 17th February 1982) joined Inter back in the summer of 2001. He featured for the Nerazzurri up until the 2008-09 campaign (during which he spent loan spells with Fiorentina, Parma and San Paolo). In Milan he made a total of 177 Inter appearances, scoring 74 goals. He won three Scudetti, two Coppa Italia trophies and three Supercoppa Italiana titles. He represented the Brazil National Team on 48 occasions and scored 27 goals. With the Green and Yellows he won the Copa America and the Confederations Cup.

Ex-Inter president Massimo Moratti praised Spalletti and his team in an interview with La Gazzetta dello Sport: "I had already thought of Spalletti as Inter coach after the Treble, in 2010. I told Branca to speak to him, but then he decided to go to Zenit. In some ways he is similar to Mourinho. He can get into players' head like Josè and the environment of mutual trust that he creates is very positive for the team. The difference between him and Conte is that Luciano has never won the Scudetto and he sees Inter as his chance to do it, while Conte has won both in England and in Italy. If he had failed to win here, it would have been Inter's fault, not his. Icardi? Now he plays for the team and he has still the energy to score goals. The €110 million buyout clause should be increased".

Moratti also talked about Suning and the main rivals: "Suning has a deep respect for the rules, but I'm sure that they will do everything they can on the transfer market to adjust the team. On Saturday we will face Juventus, I hope that will be a great match. Both teams are in their best period of form and Allegri is a great coach, but I have faith in Spalletti. About Milan, they have changed many players so it could have been understandable to see them in trouble, but I couldn't imagine this many. Their are 18 points behind us now, and I would lie if I said that I was sorry about it".

"I have played with [Icardi], he's a very good player who scores a lot of goals," Kovacic told Spanish daily Marca.

"But we have the best forward in the world, which is Karim. Icardi is good and could help us for sure, but I don't talk about signings."

Inter sporting director Piero Ausilio said earlier this week that the Serie A club were under no pressure to sell the €200m-rated Icardi to Real Madrid, pointing out that the player had more than three years left on his contract at San Siro.

The Genie of the Lamp
Storia N.18/110


It’s said that Alexander the Great saw his story reflected in the legend of Achilles and that Charles XII of Sweden saw his own in that of Alexander. Zlatan Ibrahimovic was a Swedish ruler of men but on the football pitch and he must have experienced the same sensation when he looked at Ronaldo while in a trance during the second derby of the 2006-7 season.

Ronaldo was my idol, as a player he was complete. There will never be a player better than him.

The forward who was then playing for Milan was the idol of his youth. Zlatan grew up in a tough part of Malmö. He’d watch his exploits and dreamt of imitating them and now he was up against him as an opponent for the first (and only) time in his career. There was no time to be distracted by memories though. At the end of the first half the Rossoneri were 1-0 up (thanks to a goal from the Brazilian himself) and it was on Ibrahimovic to carry the team on his shoulders. In the second half, after glancing at his favourite player with a sense of admiration while being ready for the challenge, Zlatan outdid Ronaldo with an assist and a goal, winning the hearts of the Nerazzurri fans after a meeting between top class players.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AMPyWIstERU
Zlatan Ibrahimovic - Inter

With the Inter shirt, Ibrahimovic would reach heights not even scaled by O Fenômeno. He won the league three times and was top scorer once. He made his mark on the Nerazzurri successes of those years with pieces of play that disarmed opponents and true sporting masterpieces. One of which was his brace which delivered the club’s 16th Scudetto. On the final day of the 2007-8 season, Inter were drawing 0-0 with Parma while Roma were winning at Catania and set to become champions of Italy. At the start of the second half, Roberto Mancini brought Ibrahimovic on after he’d been out for a month and a half with a knee injury. It was like rubbing the lamp to summon the genie for a wish. Zlatan came on and scored twice to sew the Scudetto to his chest. During the raucous title celebrations, it’s said that all of the players went to thank the Coach. All but one. “You’re welcome,” said Zlatan.


ZLATAN IBRAHIMOVIC

Zlatan Ibrahimovic (Malmö, 3rd October 1981) joined Inter from Juventus in 2006 for €24.8 million. With the Nerazzurri, he played in 117 matches and scored 66 goals as he won the Scudetto three times and the Supercoppa Italiana twice. In 2008-9, he finished as top scorer with 25 goals. A world class player, he also represented Ajax, Milan, Barcelona, Paris Saint-Germain and Manchester United, winning at least a title at each. With 62 goals from 166 matches, he’s the all-time top scorer for Sweden.

Felipe Melo: "I could never say bad things about Juve, but Inter is in my heart"

Brazilian midfielder Felipe Melo knows well the feeling of playing a "derby d'Italia", since he played both for Juventus and Inter: "I could never say bad things about Juve, but Inter is in my heart - said the Brazilian in an interview with La Gazzetta dello Sport - In matches like this anything can happen. If Inter gets a result at the Allianz Stadium, they could aim for the Serie A title. Icardi is always a decisive player, he won back the love of the supporters, he is a true interista. He deserves to be the captain."
